articles.headline: Toyota’s Top U.S. Executive Is Joining Chrysler
articles.snippet: James E. Press has been lured away from Toyota to serve as Chrysler’s co-president as the company continues its transformation.
articles.abstract: James E. Press has been lured away from Toyota to serve as Chrysler’s co-president as the company continues its transformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Sept. 6 — For a generation, waves of Detroit auto executives have been defecting to foreign rivals.

articles.headline: Jobs Abroad Support ‘Model’ State in India
articles.snippet: The Indian state of Kerala, celebrated for its alternative model of development, is dependent on remittances.
articles.abstract: The Indian state of Kerala, celebrated for its alternative model of development, is dependent on remittances.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIVANDRUM, India — This verdant swath of southern Indian coastline is a famously good place to be poor. People in the state of Kerala live nearly as long as Americans do, on a sliver of the income. They read at nearly the same rates.

articles.headline: As Housing Market Cools, Far Fewer Become Agents
articles.snippet: When the housing market was booming, many rushed in to the residential real estate business. Now a growing number of agents are looking for other employment.
articles.abstract: When the housing market was booming, many rushed in to the residential real estate business. Now a growing number of agents are looking for other employment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even when Leon Maldonado was getting his real estate license three years ago, he saw that the red-hot housing market in San Diego was beginning to cool. But he decided to forge ahead.

articles.headline: IPhone Owners Crying Foul Over Price Cut
articles.snippet: On Thursday, Apple C.E.O. Steven P. Jobs acknowledged that the company had abused its core customers’ trust and extended a $100 store credit to the early iPhone buyers.
articles.abstract: On Thursday, Apple C.E.O. Steven P. Jobs acknowledged that the company had abused its core customers’ trust and extended a $100 store credit to the early iPhone buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 — In June, they were calling it the God Phone. On Thursday, it was the Chump Phone.
articles.byline: By Katie Hafner and Brad Stone

articles.headline: For Thompson, Goal Is to Don Reagan Mantle
articles.snippet: Fred D. Thompson is trying to win over conservatives by positioning himself as the ideological and stylistic heir of Ronald Reagan.
articles.abstract: Fred D. Thompson is trying to win over conservatives by positioning himself as the ideological and stylistic heir of Ronald Reagan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fred D. Thompson had one central strategic goal as he formally began his presidential campaign on Thursday: to win over conservatives who are disheartened at their current choice of Republican candidates by positioning himself as the ideological and stylistic heir of Ronald Reagan.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Pension Effect From Tax Plan Is Called Slight
articles.snippet: A proposal to double the tax rate of executives at private equity firms would have negligible impact on the returns received by pensioners, specialists told Congress Thursday.
articles.abstract: A proposal to double the tax rate of executives at private equity firms would have negligible impact on the returns received by pensioners, specialists told Congress Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 — Pension fund and tax specialists told Congress on Thursday that a proposal to more than double the tax rate of executives at private equity and hedge funds, who invest retirement monies, would have negligible impact on the returns received by pensioners.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: In Plot Suspect, Germany Sees Familiar Face
articles.snippet: Interviews and documents sketch a picture of the German native charged in a terror plot as a troubled young man.
articles.abstract: Interviews and documents sketch a picture of the German native charged in a terror plot as a troubled young man.
articles.lead_paragraph: ULM, Germany, Sept. 6 — Legally, his name is as German as they come: Fritz. To his new confidants in the radical Islamic scene and alleged terrorist co-conspirators, he was Abdullah.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Toy Makers Seek Standards for U.S. Safety
articles.snippet: After a series of recalls that have undermined public confidence, the nation’s largest toy makers are asking the government to impose mandatory testing standards.
articles.abstract: After a series of recalls that have undermined public confidence, the nation’s largest toy makers are asking the government to impose mandatory testing standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  Acknowledging a growing crisis of public confidence caused by a series of recent recalls, the nation’s largest toy makers have taken the unusual step of asking the federal government to impose mandatory safety-testing standards for all toys sold in the United States.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Louise Story

articles.headline: So This Subprime Lender Walks Into an Audit...
articles.snippet: Deloitte effectively revokes its audit of NovaStar and the subprime mortgage lender stands on shaky ground.
articles.abstract: Deloitte effectively revokes its audit of NovaStar and the subprime mortgage lender stands on shaky ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: The auditor got cold feet, and the company may die.
